captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: There are few cars
more iconic than the 1980s
Porsche 911.

The shape is instantly
recognizable
and positively timeless.

And to this day, that generation
of 911 is about the

most robust and durable
platform
Stuttgart has ever offered.

It racked up just as much
success on the racetrack as it
did on the showroom floor.

And legions of enthusiasts since
have proven that with

proper maintenance, it can be
essentially driven forever.

You may remember BBI Autosport
from the first ever episode of

"Tuned." These guys build
everything Porsche, from huge

power, standing-mile monsters to
fully prepped GT race cars,

fast daily drivers, and
everything in-between.

So when co-owner Joey Seely
wanted to build his perfect

weekend warrior, of course
it had to be a 911.

But for the first time in BBI's
history, this 911 would
be cooled by air.

Three years of work later,
and this is the result--

a modern vision of what the
GT3 RS would be had
it existed in 1985.

And we think that even Porsche's
top engineers today

would appreciate Joey's
subtle details.

From the repurposed rear wing,
to the vintage-look HRE

wheels, to the stripped yet
clean and tidy interior, to

the exhaust plumbed directly
through the rear bumper, it's

clear that this 911 showed
up to party.

This is the type of car you'd
expect to see vintage racing
at Laguna Seca.

And though you may see it at
the track, the runway,

autocross, or car show on the
weekends, from Monday to

Friday, it's just how
Joey gets to work.

We think it bridges the gap
perfectly between race car,

show car, and driver, which is
why, once again, we will

demonstrate that all great drive
stories start like this.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Get your commenting
fingers ready.
"Tuned" is back.

There is really a lot to
love about this car.

First and foremost, of course,
is the weight.

Under 2,200 pounds wet and
with a 3.6-liter flat-6,

making 275 horsepower at the
wheels, that's many hundreds

of pounds lighter than stock,
with 100 more wheel horsepower
than stock.

So the power to weight
ratio of this
car is pretty brilliant.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: The sound
is off the chain.
Incredible.

Only thing is, on the 80-mile
transit down here, I sure got

a lot of it and required
some Advil afterwards.

Working with the brilliant
minds at BBI offers many

rewards and only
one downside--
location.

The nearest good roads are
nearly 80 miles from the shop,

and that means a long, loud
transit in which I'll get

accustomed to this car that
probably wants me dead.
Lesson one--

if the owner leaves ear plugs
in the glove box, even he
knows it's too loud.
Lesson two--

80s 911s, especially when
modified to this level, are
not exactly easy to drive.
That's part of their charm.

It takes a simultaneous firm
hand and a soft touch, perfect

timing, and plenty of
patience, like a

high-maintenance girlfriend
and one that makes just as
much noise.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: There is nothing
in this car.
That's why it's so light.

There's no climate control
of any kind.
There's no radio.
There's no power door locks.
There are power windows.

The mirror doesn't
really work.

There's no insulation or
sound-deadening anywhere.
There aren't even vents here.

But the car runs on 100 octane,
which we can't even
get around here.

So we have to make sure we can
get the car back to Joey on

the tank of gas that
we're using.
JOEY SEELY: It's like camping.

There's no heat, no AC, no
radio, no carpet, solid
suspension bushings.
It's really loud.

Like I said, it's a track
car that's street legal.

It starts with ERP's 935
suspension control arms and

sub-frames from the 935 race
cars back in the day--

KW Competition triple dampers;
Tarett Engineering sway bars

and drop links and camber
plates, so everything's solid;

big Brembos from Race
Technologies; HRE wheels, the

935-look wheels, kind of a bold
statement, for the street

anyways, kind of like
a show wheel.

The motor is a 3.6-liter flat-6
from an RS America that

we were supposed to
reseal, which is
the famous last words.

We opened it up, and then Jared,
my engine builder, went
a little haywire with PTM.

And now it has basically a
stronger and lighter bottom
end than the 993 RSR.

It's got a titanium connecting
rods from the GT3 Cup car, GT3

oil pump, big duration cam,
high-compression pistons, high

rev springs, pretty much just
about everything, including an

AM standalone that we had tuned
by our friend Mikey next
door at Autowave.

MATT FARAH: I swear to God,
though, 275 at the wheel's
never felt so fast.
This thing grips.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Oh, and it stops
really good, too.

Not much pedal pressure
required there.

Big Brembo brakes doing their
job there on the Falken tires.

The Recaro seats, real
comfortable.

This is, of course, my special
seat, because I can't fit in
Joey's seat.

So they keep this
one in the shop.

When I want to come drive the
car, they pop it in for me in
the big boy's size.

Now before you guys get all
up in arms that I'm just

describing driving any old
911, not this one in

particular, Alex Roy has a 1987
Porsche Carrera that I

took out for about 200 miles
in preparation for this.

My homework is very
difficult, I know.

And the differences between
that car and this car are

basically like the differences
between a modern Carrera and
like a GT3 RS--

way lighter, way louder, way
more responsive, Much more

like a race inside,
much more spartan.

JOEY SEELY: The front bumper
is a replica of the Ruf

Yellowbird back in--
what was that? '87?

Just a nice clean look, but
still not getting too far out

of what the original design of
the car was, Not too new
school, not too old school.

We closed the sun roof, welded
it shut, so that lost another

50 pounds or so off the top
of the car way up high.

The rear bumper is a replica
of a '74 RS.

But it's a little bit wider for
the rear flare that we put

the exhaust through the bumper
next to the license plate,

which we've always had an idea
of doing that, just doing
something kind of clever.

And then the tail is from
a '76 Turbo Carrera.

They don't make the rubber
black foam piece
anymore for that tail.

So I had to take the original
Carrera tail rubber, trim it

down, and shape it to fit this
one, which gives it a little
more kick up in the back.

The only challenge of building
the car is a budget because

the shoemaker has no shoes,
so budget and time.

I always felt guilty working
on it when I've got
customers' cars here.
So it took a little while.

Now it's finally done,
and it's paid off.
And the challenges--

no, there really wasn't too many
challenges, except for

we're not versed in the
air-cooled so much as we are

in the newer water-cooled
cars.

MATT FARAH: I just find it
interesting that after being

around all that horsepower all
the time, all that technology,

all that boost, he
wants this--
light.

No radio, no air conditioning,
no anything, sorta how I feel

after doing two seasons of
"Tune." Forget horsepower.

Let's keep things light
and raw dog.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: There's a lot of
little details in the car that

really give you a
great indication
of the car's purpose.

The CNC aluminum foot rest on
the floor, the one-piece
shifter, no boot.

There's nothing to clutter it
up, the Momo Prototipo wheel.

Now that we've learned the new
GT3 RS and the new Turbo are

not going to come with manual
transmissions anymore, it's

really nice to know that these
chassis will be out there.

And for what is probably
a lot less money,
you could have this.
Oh yeah.

Roll up to any car show, roll
up to any racetrack, any

event, any Targa or Bullrun
event, and just have the

coolest car around, man, because
this is a classy move.

And I love that it's
not a show car.
It's not mint.

It's got nicks and chips on
it, because he drives
the hell out of it.
[CAR ENGINE]

JOEY SEELY: People like
vintage stuff now.

They like anything that's
got craft--

craft beers and craft coffee,
and all that stuff.

So they like the old character
of this car.

And they do like that
it's nasty.
It's loud.
It's low.
It's got style.
And it's surprisingly fast.

They're not expecting that
out of 1985 technology.

The current trend with the
wide-body stuff, like RWB is
pretty cool.
We considered doing it.

But for us, form follows
function.

And I wasn't going to be
doing big, big power.

I more wanted to go lighter
and slipperier,
like the 996 Cup cars--

nice and narrow and just
screaming fast.

All we did was just massage the
fenders for a little more

wheel clearance under
compression.

Not necessarily a wider tire,
which we do have wider tires,
but it was more for up travel.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: I'll admit
I was a little torn
when I first saw it.

When he said "white wheels," I
was like, oh no, you didn't

just say "white wheels." But
seeing them on the car, it's

really got a Porsche motorsport
thing happening

there, sort of a Group B,
Porsche 935 race car look on

HR3 wheels, brand new
modern wheels.

That's my favorite thing
about this car.

It's a really proper, seamless
integration of old world feel,

old world vibe, with new world
technology driving it.

I hope they build more of
these, so I can buy one.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Though the car
never skipped a beat,
it was a long day.

Joey's Porsche is hot, loud,
unforgiving if you're not

brave enough to trust it, and
keeps you on your toes more so

than nearly any other streetcar
I've driven.

It beats you up with its heavy
controls and booming exhaust

and confirmed in my own head
that, no, I have no interest

in building a summer home
inside of a muffler.

However, as an example of what
an old Carrera is capable of

when built right, Joey's
car is simply perfect.

It's stupendously fast,
bulletproof reliable, gorgeous
and tasteful from every angle.

And there isn't a weak link to
be found anywhere in the car.

You can literally feel that the
owner knows race cars and
knows them well.

And without any insulation or
rubber to soften the blow,

every part of your
senses feels that
engineering at work.

The completeness of the build
becomes immediately apparent

the first time you chuck
it into a corner.

In the beginning, I said that
this 911 is what a GT3 RS

might have been had they
made one in 1985.
But the truth is, it's not.
It's much better.

comments.text:
Making it light by removing instead of modifying with lighter components is 
for amateurs.﻿
comments.author: Bobby Weedman

comments.text:
It's two different approaches. Replacing existing components with lighter 
ones will certainly make the car lighter while keeping it similar in Terms 
of comfort, but you will never get the amount of weight loss like when you 
strip the car out. So when Performance is your only goal, and you don't 
give a fuck about comfort, just removing everything is way cheaper and also 
way more effective.

comments.author: tydi tgh

comments.text:
My hat's off to, Joey for having the nuts to drive this thing day in day 
out, but I'd have none of it. I'd love it for track days, but there is 
something to be said about a relaxed, leisurely, comfortable commute in 
supple leather.

The engine loud enough to hear the song of the motor when pressed, but not 
so loud that a light weight premium sound system playing some Joe 
Bonamassa  would get lost in it. To live in Alaska would be the only place 
I'd even think of doing without AC, & more manly color of dark charcoal 
gray with lighter, matte black mesh BBS's.

But every mans obsession is their own & it'd be a boring, stark raving mad 
world if everyone was the same. If this world would come back to it's 
senses, maybe I two could afford my dream Porsche 911. Not you Joe, I like 
your kind of madness.﻿

comments.author: Oscar Barrera

comments.text:
+Oscar Barrera Thank you for your kind words, but writing about cars is a 
passion of mine, and would love to write about them for a living, but 
instead I write for the love of the humble car for free, via youtube and 
chat rooms. But what else can I say about the Singer 911, it is utter 
perfection...
comments.author: Adam Jenkins

comments.text:
i would Love to take one out for a drive. the why those cars look iv always

comments.author: Oscar Barrera

comments.text:
Singer 911s are works of art, they belong on a public platform for the 
world to witness there beauty, I'd happily drive one round for them, if 
they need someone to fulfil this public service. The perfect car in my 
world, nothing comes close to them in the form of a usable supercar that is 
so understated that it would fit in with all classes of people, forget the 
hyper supercars your Veyrons, Ferraris, Zondas and Koenigseggs. They bring 
to much theatre to the proceedings of the word 'car'. It should bring about 
a simplistic child-like quality and when I was young, it was the simple 
shape of those early 911s that made it for me, sometimes 'less is more' and 
the Singer is perfect in everyway!
comments.author: Adam Jenkins

comments.author: Poopy mcpooperfart

comments.text:
+Nue Gai I prefer the 911 to the Corvette as well, obviously, but I don't 
know how anyone can knock it like you just did. It's a hugely successful 
platform in racing, it's very reliable, it's inexpensive yet while offering 
performance that rivals cars that are twice, maybe even three times as 
expensive, and it's surprisingly efficient as well. And by the way, Matt 
owns an Aston Martin Vanquish as well.
